ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Benchmarks?
ygData.msgSnippet:
Hi,

 I suspect the same problem is still present in game playing since you
 can only evaluate a small proportion of the possible paths in the game -
 usually

Hi,

>I suspect the same problem is still present in game playing since you
>can only evaluate a small proportion of the possible paths in the game -
>usually determined by the opponents you are playing against. In fact
>with co-evolution the networks will normally (I think) end up playing
>within a very narrow range of game strategies - which means they perform
>poorly when played against humans or even simple algorithmic strategies
>they have never encountered before. Although I'm happy to be proved
>wrong on this, that partly my experience so in some limited Tic-Tac-Toe
>co-evolution experiments I've been working on (more on those another time).

I was talking to somebody on a newsgroup about just this point (it wasn't 
you, was it?)

Anyway, this is what I said.  I'm just posting it really because it's the 
longest URL I've ever seen :)

http://groups-beta.google.com/group/comp.ai.neural-nets/browse_frm/thread/68a1a0ebd5fc7a27/a901d35657afdd35?tvc=1&q=%22Ian+Badcoe%22#a901d35657afdd35

It's probably well within the standard level of discussions we already had 
in the group...

         Ian

In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
